awd_titl_txt: Sequestration of Halogens in the Sub-continental Lithospheric Mantle: Implications for Global Element Cycling
awd_abstract_narration:
The halogen elements (chlorine, fluorine, iodine, and bromine) play a fundamental role in modifying the properties of fluids and minerals on Earth. For example, the addition of halogens to fluids can cause minerals to break down at different temperatures and pressures, as well as, increase the ability of the fluid to transport of metals. Halogens are enriched in surface reservoirs (e.g., sedimentary pore fluids, sediments) compared to the Earth's mantle. The subduction of these reservoirs brings halogens into the mantle. Halogens can then be returned to the Earth's surface at arc volcanoes. However, mass balance constraints suggest that more halogens are subducted to the mantle than are returned to the Earth's surface via arc volcanism. These observations lead most researchers to suggest that an excess of halogens are being continually delivered to the mantle. This imbalance as implications for the long-term chemical evolution of the Earth's surficial reservoirs and mantle. However, several halogen reservoirs remain unquantified and may account for this disconnect. Here it is proposed that halogens may be sequestered in the sub-continental lithospheric mantle (i.e., the upper mantle below the base of the continental crust) and thus not accounted for in calculations. By quantifying the concentrations of halogens in the sub-continental lithospheric mantle, the overall halogen budget can be constrained. In addition to the intellectual impacts of improved understanding of elemental transfer through subductions zones, the broader impacts involve training of graduate and undergraduate students and participation in GeoFORCE, a summer program that engages outstanding students from select low performing minority-serving high schools in STEM fields.

This work will constrain the effects of subduction on the subcontinental lithospheric mantle halogen budget and the extent to which the subcontinental lithospheric mantle may act as a major halogen reservoir and control the overall halogen budget by "isolating" halogens from the subduction zone cycle for potentially long periods of time. This work will also provide insights as to how subduction processes modify the halogen concentrations and ratios in material returned to the convecting mantle. Bulk halogen concentrations, as well as, in situ halogen concentrations of hydrous (e.g., chlorite, amphibole, antigorite) and anhydrous minerals (e.g., pyroxene, olivine) of mantle xenoliths from the western United States that have been geochemically modified by the subducting Farallon slab will be measured. These data will be compared with other lithophile tracers of subduction input and melt depletion. The subduction-influenced xenoliths will be compared to non-subduction-modified mantle xenoliths and abyssal peridotites, which will serve as a baseline for halogen content in the convecting mantle.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Halogen elements (F, Cl, Br, and I) are enriched in the Earth's surface relative to the Earth's interior (i.e., mantle). Subduction of surficial material conveys halogens into the mantle and can result in variable enrichment. These halogen elements play a fundamental role in modifying the properties of the Earth's interior. For example, they can affect the temperature at which minerals will melt and change how minerals deform, thus having implications for mantle dynamics, melt production, and volcanism. However, the halogen budget, including the quantity, distribution, and source of halogens, of the sub-continental lithospheric mantle (i.e., the upper mantle below the base of the continental crust) is poorly constrained. To address this uncertainty, this study examined the halogen concentrations and chlorine isotope ratios of mantle rocks, primarily from the southwestern United States, which have been returned to the Earth's surface via volcanic pipes. We measured the bulk rock halogen concentrations, as well as in situ halogen concentrations of hydrous (i.e., water-bearing) and anhydrous minerals that have been geochemically modified to varying degrees by fluids and melts produced via a subducting slab approximately 30-80 million years ago.

This study finds that the mantle beneath the southwestern United States has been variably enriched in Cl, Br, and I from a hydrous fluid, but only minorly enriched in F. The source of this fluid is Cl-rich and F-depleted; and it has a high chlorine isotope ratio relative to the mantle, suggesting fluid contribution from dehydrating lower crust in the subducting plate. Because these samples are located more than 800 km from the paleo-subduction zone, the observed signature indicates that Cl, Br, and H2O can be retained to great distances, resulting in widespread hydrous geochemical modification. Such retention is likely the result of residual high-pressure hydrous phases in the lower crust of the subducting plate. The in situ halogen data show that, when present, hydrous minerals largely control the F and Cl budget. Additionally, the in situ data were used to examine the effects of various parameters on F and Cl partitioning between anhydrous minerals, showing that the composition of the mineral pyroxene largely controls F partitioning, whereas Cl incorporation is a function of the elastic modulus of the mineral. Overall, this work shows that although there is no single halogen endmember composition for the sub-continental lithospheric mantle, the preservation of halogen heterogeneity, both in concentrations and isotopic compositions, makes halogens useful tracers of subduction processes in mantle materials.

This study extends the use of chlorine isotope ratios as a tracer of subduction to oceanic lavas, which are products of mantle melting. Measured lavas that incorporated subducted materials (i.e., sediment, altered oceanic crust) span a large range of chlorine isotope ratios. Previous disparate estimates of the mantle source composition to oceanic volcanism are likely the result of subduction-derived geochemical heterogeneity in the mantle that were previously unrecognized. This study demonstrates that the chlorine isotope ratio of the mantle that has not interacted with subducted material is similar to early formed chondritic meteorites. Oceanic lavas, both from this study and from limited previous studies, that fall farther from that chondritic value all show signs of incorporation of subducted material, and thus are not representative of the ambient mantle. These findings have implications for the source of volatile elements like hydrogen, carbon, and chlorine on the early Earth, as well as the long-term exchange of volatile elements between Earth's surface and mantle.

The work supported the education and scientific training of graduate and undergraduate students. It provided support via collaborative work to the Northeast National Ion Microprobe Facility (NENIMF) at the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution (WHOI). This work also strengthened international collaborations with researchers at the Freie University in Berlin, Germany and University of Lausanne, Switzerland. International colleagues helped with transfer of knowledge regarding the methodological and analytical set-up of some of the halogen analyses, including laboratory cross calibration.
